data.title: ICE Review: Canola Retreats to Pause Rally
data.description:
WINNIPEG, Manitoba--Canola futures on the Intercontinental Exchange were in negative territory on Friday despite rising comparable oils.

Chicago soyoil was up slightly with an analyst saying any time it is between 60 to 65 United States cents per pound was "a bonus." European rapeseed was mostly higher and Malaysian palm oil was up as well. Crude oil gained nearly US$2 per barrel after nuclear talks between the United States and Iran ended today without a resolution.

China confirmed on Friday it's suspending its tariffs on Canadian agricultural imports, including canola meal, starting March 1. China's duty on Canadian canola seed will be reduced to 15 per cent on the same day.

The Canadian Grain Commission reported 243,600 tonnes were exported during the week ended Feb. 22, down from the 257,100 shipped the previous week. So far this marketing year, canola exports totalled 4.269 million tonnes, compared to 6.021 million one year ago.

At mid-afternoon, the Canadian dollar was up three-tenths of a U.S. cent compared to Thursday's close.

There were 56,485 canola contracts traded on Friday, compared to Thursday when 67,563 contracts changed hands. Spreads accounted for 39,586 contracts in today's trade.

Settlement prices are in Canadian dollars per metric tonne.

data.title: After His House Burned Down, He Built a $3 Million Fire-Resistant Home — WSJ
data.description:
By Kerry Barger

This is an edition of the WSJ Homes newsletter, a weekly guide to luxurious properties, celebrity homes, interior design and the housing market. If you're not subscribed, sign up here.

When Ardie Tavangarian lost his Pacific Palisades home to the L.A. wildfires last January, he didn't want to build another one that would burn easily. So the developer refocused his professional life on a new mission: creating an extremely fire-resistant home to serve as a model for rebuilding.

"I realized that it didn't make sense to continue to build these defenseless structures when this could potentially happen again," he says.

He has just finished building a roughly 4,200-square-foot, four-bedroom home for his twin daughters on the grounds of the family's Palisades estate, which is designed to resist an active fire for up to six hours. There is a $325,000 fire-detection system that uses satellites, heat sensors and AI-powered cameras to detect fires nearby, and $400,000 worth of windows that are made from a durable, heat-resistant glass and framed by metal shutters that can be closed remotely.

"What he's done is the model," said fire-protection engineer Nate Wittasek, who has toured the home. Its features exceed the requirements of the new California fire code "by at least a factor of two, and in many cases substantially more," he said.

You may know New Zealand as a place where tech billionaires go to build their "doom-prep" bunkers. But the country is riding a new wave of American buyers, many of them venture capitalists, entrepreneurs and investment advisers drawn to the country's vibrant startup community. Adding fuel to the fire is a recent shift in New Zealand's visa policies, which makes it easier for wealthy foreigners to buy homes in the country.

Kiwi real-estate agents say they are being flooded with calls from Americans. "The draw is lifestyle, political stability and safety," said Mischa Mannix-Opie at Greener Pastures New Zealand, an investment manager and visa-advisory firm. "Being able to buy a home is the icing."

What a $3 Million Fire-Resistant Home Looks Like

After losing his house to the L.A. wildfires, a developer built a new one designed to resist an active fire for around six hours.

New Zealand Rolls Out the Welcome Mat for Wealthy American Home Buyers

The country's budding startup scene and changes to its Active Investor Plus visa program have led to an influx of venture capitalists, entrepreneurs and advisers.

What's the Deal

In 2022, billionaire Citadel founder Ken Griffin bought a waterfront estate in Coconut Grove for $106.875 million, setting a record for Miami-Dade County. Now, Griffin's next-door neighbors are listing their home for $110 million.

Former NFL wide receiver Danny Amendola sold his Midcentury-Modern home in the Austin, Texas, area for $3.6 million last month. The two-time Super Bowl champion didn't have to move far. He already owned the house next door.

A penthouse at an under-construction condominium on Manhattan's Upper East Side is in contract to be sold for its asking price of $89.5 million — a potential sales record for the neighborhood, according to the developer.

Want to see more deals? Sign up for our Mansion Deals email alert to have the biggest and best luxury home sales and listings delivered to your inbox.

The Luxe Life

One couple spent six years and some $7 million painstakingly renovating a Paul Rudolph-designed home in Delray Beach. But a nonprofit tied to the architect claims their extensive rebuilding stripped the property of authenticity.

Before Jeremy Irons turned to acting, he nearly joined the circus. "At one traveling circus, I walked around the caravans and came to the conclusion I was too middle-class for those living conditions."

House of the Week

Will WSJ's House of the Month for February be a Scotland estate with a pub and Pilates studio, a Modernist home tucked into the L.A. hillside, or a Santa Fe compound with space for horses? Vote now.

Your Home

  • Last year the U.S. experienced something that hasn't definitively occurred since the Great Depression: More people moved out than moved in.
  • The average 30-year fixed mortgage rate fell to 5.98% this week, the lowest level since September 2022.
  • Austin's rental market is projected to become more expensive, with rents expected to remain flat or even increase after at least 10 quarters of decreases.

About Us

Thanks for reading! Send us your comments and questions, and be sure to follow us on Facebook, X and Instagram.

Kerry Barger is Mansion's senior platform editor. Say hi at Kerry.Barger@wsj.com or connect with her on LinkedIn.

Candace Taylor is the editor of Mansion. Reach her at Candace.Taylor@wsj.com.

data.title: US natgas futures edge up on higher global energy prices, near-record LNG exports
data.description:
Key points:
  • Gas futures rise despite warmer weather forecasts
  • Texas Waha Hub prices negative for 16th consecutive day
  • LNG export flows near record levels in February

By Scott DiSavino

U.S. natural gas futures edged up on Friday on near-record liquefied natural gas export flows and higher global energy prices amid concerns over potential supply disruptions due to tensions between the United States and Iran .

The increase in gas futures came despite forecasts for warmer weather and lower heating demand over the next two weeks than previously expected.

Front-month gas futures for April delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange rose 3.2 cents, or 1.1%, to settle at $2.859 per million British thermal units. On Thursday, the contract closed at its lowest since September 22.

For the week, the front-month was down about 6%, putting it down for a fifth week in a row for the first time since August 2025. During the past five weeks, the contract was down by around 45%.

For the month, the front-month was down about 34% in February after rising about 18% in January.

In the cash market, average prices at the Waha Hub (NG-WAH-WTX-SNL) in West Texas remained in negative territory for a record 16th day in a row, as pipeline constraints trapped gas in the nation's biggest oil-producing basin.

Daily Waha prices first averaged below zero in 2019. They did so 17 times in 2019, six times in 2020, once in 2023, a record 49 times in 2024, 39 times in 2025, and 25 times so far this year.

Waha prices have averaged 40 cents per mmBtu so far in 2026, compared with $1.15 in 2025 and $2.88 over the past five years (2021-2025).

In Northern California, next-day gas at the PG&E Citygate (NG-CG-PGE-SNL) fell to a record low of $1.37 per mmBtu. That compares with the prior all-time low of $1.43 in November 2001 and averages of $2.30 so far in 2026, $3.42 in 2025, and $5.47 over the past five years (2021-2025).

SUPPLY AND DEMAND

Average gas output in the Lower 48 states climbed to 108.7 billion cubic feet per day (bcfd) so far in February, up from 106.3 bcfd in January, according to data from financial firm LSEG. That compares with a monthly record high of 109.7 bcfd in December.

Energy analysts projected a winter storm earlier this week likely caused energy firms to pull more gas out of storage than usual for this time of year, knocking stockpiles down from near-normal levels during the week ended February 20 to about 2% below normal for the week ended February 27.

But with meteorologists predicting weather across the country will remain mostly warmer than normal through March 14, analysts expect stockpiles to reach above-normal levels by mid-March.

LSEG projected average gas demand in the Lower 48 states, including exports, would drop from 137.6 bcfd this week to 125.3 bcfd next week and 112.9 bcfd in two weeks. The forecasts for this week and next were lower than LSEG's outlook on Thursday.

Average gas flows to the nine large U.S. LNG export plants rose to 18.7 bcfd so far in February, up from 17.8 bcfd in January and on track to beat December's monthly record of 18.5 bcfd.

data.title: Wheat Futures Higher as Short Covering Keeps Going — Daily Grain Highlights
data.description:
By Kirk Maltais

  • Wheat for May delivery rose 3% to $5.91 1/2 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade on Friday, with a continued push in short-covering coming as some analysts eye weather conditions globally, while futures also took cues from a risk-off macro environment.
  • Corn for May delivery rose 1.1% to $4.48 1/4 a bushel.
  • Soybeans for May delivery rose 0.6% to $11.70 a bushel.

HIGHLIGHTS

Catching Fire: There are multiple reasons why traders continue to cover their short positions in wheat, Commerzbank said in a note. Part of it has to do with droughts and wildfires in the U.S. Midwest, as well as a deterioration in crop health in France. An attack by Russia on Ukrainian infrastructure in the port city of Odesa, and tensions between the U.S. and Iran that has traders across markets adjusting their positions.

Taking Cues: Corn futures rose to the highest their level this year. The grain received support from higher crude oil futures as U.S.-Iran tensions remain unresolved heading into the weekend. "The two sides will resume more technical discussions next week in Vienna," StoneX's said Arlan Suderman in a note. "A bulked-up U.S. military presence in the Middle East remains." Corn's price is tied to oil due to ethanol, which is a major consumer of commodity that is an ingredient blended into American motor fuel.

INSIGHT

Overseas Interest: The USDA reported a flash sale of U.S. corn exports for the second consecutive day, this time in a notice that said 257,000 metric tons were headed to "unknown destinations" for delivery in the 2025/26 marketing year. That phrase when included in USDA statements is often--but not always--used in connection with China. Grain traders continue to look for confirmation of China buying more U.S. soybeans.

Sticking Around: The latest U.S. inflation gauge showed price increases are likely to remain above the Federal Reserve's 2% target for a while. January's producer price index unexpectedly accelerated, and other indicators are expected to show inflation remains stubborn. "The data out this morning actually points to inflation being a nagging frustration for the U.S. economy," Comerica's Bill Adams said. The Fed is expected to remain cautious when considering rate cuts in the coming months. Attitudes around inflation and rate cuts tend to affect how commodities trade.

AHEAD

  • The USDA will release its weekly Grain Export Inspections report at 11 a.m. ET Monday.
  • The USDA will release its monthly Grain Crushings report at 3 p.m. ET Monday.
  • The EIA will release its Weekly Petroleum Status Update report at 10:30 a.m. ET Wednesday.

Paulo Trevisani contributed to this article

Write to Kirk Maltais at kirk.maltais@wsj.com

data.title: Oil prices climb to a 7-month high as Trump signals military attack on Iran is still on the table
data.description:
By Barbara Kollmeyer

U.S. government on Friday urges nonemergency government workers to leave Israel

The State Department on Friday urged nonemergency U.S. workers to leave Israel after talks on Tehran's nuclear program ended Thursday without a deal.

Oil prices were up sharply Friday after President Donald Trump reportedly suggested that a U.S. military strike on Iran is still being considered after a deal to end Tehran's nuclear ambitions didn't materialize this week.

Trump told reporters outside the White House that he would "love not to use" the U.S. military to attack Iran, but "sometimes you have to," according to a report from CNBC.

Oil prices moved back up toward session highs in the wake of those reported comments. April West Texas Intermediate crude (CLJ26) (CL.1) rose 2.6% to $66.91 a barrel. The contract is set to gain nearly 1% for the week and over 3% for the month of February, FactSet data show.

April Brent crude (BRNJ26) was up 2.5% to $72.50 a barrel, with the contract set to gain 1% for the week and 4.6% for the month.

The oil market is providing a reminder that until "documents are signed and money changes hands, there is no deal," Colin Cieszynski, portfolio manager and chief market strategist at SIA Wealth Management, told MarketWatch.

The Oman-mediated talks between the U.S. and Iran in Geneva ended on Thursday with "significant progress," Badr Albusaidi, Oman's foreign minister, said in a post on X Thursday. He said talks would resume after "consultation in the respective capitals," with the two sides holding "technical level" discussions next week in Vienna.

"Talks are extending into another week, but ironically, the longer they go on, the higher oil prices seem to go. This is because the markets are sensing that the Iranians could be stringing [President] Trump along and at one point, Mr. Trump may lose his patience and tell his negotiators to come home," Edward Meir, an analyst at Marex, said in comments emailed Friday morning.

"At the end of the day, it should not take weeks and weeks to come to an agreement and the markets are getting nervous waiting," Meir added.

Read: U.S.-Iran nuclear talks end, but with hope that negotiations continue. That still leaves the oil market in limbo.

Congressional Democrats are expected to force a vote on a war powers resolution linked to Iran next week, in a bid to prevent Trump from taking military action against Iran without the prior approval of Congress.

Friday saw the U.S. State Department authorize nonemergency U.S. government personnel and their family members to leave Israel "due to safety risks," which weren't specified. The order also warned of potential restrictions on travel to areas of Israel, the Old City of Jerusalem and the West Bank, while suggesting "persons may wish to consider leaving Israel while commercial flights are available."

Trump has said the U.S. military has assembled an armada of warships and fighter jets near Iran.

David Morrison, senior market analyst at Trade Nation, said markets are also focused on the meeting of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies on Sunday. There has been speculation that members may resume production increases starting in April, he said, after the group decided to leave output quotas unchanged for the first quarter of 2026.

"While OPEC+ estimates that supply and demand will be in balance throughout this year, the International Energy Agency maintains its forecast of an oversupply of 3.7 million barrels per day throughout 2026," Morrison said in a note to clients.

-Barbara Kollmeyer

This content was created by MarketWatch, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. MarketWatch is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: USDA Jan Farm Prices -3.9% From Dec, -10.2% From Yr Ago
data.description:
WASHINGTON (Dow Jones)--The index of prices received by U.S. farmers 
for their products in January was -3.9% From December, and -10.2% From 
a year earlier, the U.S. Department of Agriculture said Friday. 
The January Producer Price Index (PPI), published by the Bureau of Labor 
Statistics (BLS), was delayed and therefore unavailable to be used in the 
calculation of the Prices Paid Index for Commodities and Services, Interest, 
Taxes, and Farm Wage Rates (PPITW) and 25 additional sub-indexes. NASS 
calculated the average monthly change in the PPI from August 2025 to December 
2025 and applied the change to the December PPI. Once the January PPI is 
published by BLS the indexes will be updated. 
January Prices Received Index Down 3.9 Percent 
The January Prices Received Index 2011 Base (Agricultural Production), at 
116.5, decreased 3.9 percent from December and 10 percent from January 2025. 
At 89.8, the Crop Production Index was down 6.7 percent from last month but 
up 0.9 percent from the previous year. The Livestock Production Index, at 
149.6, decreased 0.1 percent from December and 21 percent from January last 
year. Producers received lower prices during January for market eggs, milk, 
lettuce, and soybeans but higher prices for cattle, broilers, calves, and 
apples. In addition to prices, the volume change of commodities marketed also 
influences the indexes. In January, there was decreased marketing of grapes, 
turkeys, hogs, and cotton and increased monthly movement for corn, soybeans, 
cattle, and strawberries. 
January Prices Paid Index Up 3.5 Percent 
The January Prices Paid Index for Commodities and Services, Interest, Taxes, 
and Farm Wage Rates (PPITW), at 158.6, is up 3.5 percent from December 2025 
and 8.0 percent from January 2025. Higher prices in January for feeder 
cattle, 
other services, feeder pigs, and taxes more than offset lower prices for milk 
cows, diesel, interest, and complete feeds.

data.description: U.S. natural gas futures gain a few cents with buoyant LNG export demand offering support amid a bearish March weather outlook. This week marked the 10th anniversary of the first shipment of LNG from Sabine Pass in Louisiana. U.S. LNG exports rose from 500 million cubic feet a day in 2016 to 15 billion cubic feet a day in 2025, and are expected to exceed 18.1 Bcf/d in 2027, the EIA said in a note. "The U.S. has eight operational LNG export terminals, and by 2031 we expect export capacity to nearly double compared with December 2025." Natural gas for April delivery settles up 1.1% at $2.859/mmBtu. (anthony.harrup@wsj.com)

data.title: Netflix Receives $2.8 Billion Fee as WBD Terminates Merger; Financing Commitments Canceled

data.title: Oil Gains on Increased Risk of U.S.-Iran Conflict — Market Talk
data.description: Oil futures settle higher as traders head into the weekend seeing heightened risk of U.S. military action against Iran. President Trump said he's not happy with the way talks are going, but that he hasn't made a final decision. He said he'd love not to use the military, "but sometimes you have to." OPEC+ is expected to agree to resume output increases in April when the group meets on Sunday. "Return of Venezuelan crude to an already well supplied market and expectations of a resumption of OPEC+ output hikes keep glut fears in focus," says Nikos Tzabouras of Tradu. "Supply-demand fundamentals remain stacked against a meaningful recovery." WTI settles up 2.8% at $67.02 a barrel and Brent rises 2.9% to $72.87. (anthony.harrup@wsj.com)

data.title: Havana rides a bicycle boom as US chokes off fuel to Cuba
data.description:
Key points:
  • US capture of Maduro cuts Cuba's fuel supply
  • Cubans turn to bicycles amid fuel scarcity
  • Demand increases for bicycle-repair businesses

By Alien Fernandez and Anett Rios

Havana residents are pulling old bicycles out of storage, patching up threadbare tires, and, in some cases, learning to cycle as fuel becomes increasingly scarce in Cuba following the U.S. takeover of Venezuela's oil exports.

Venezuela, a key ally to Cuba, had been the main supplier of crude oil and fuel to the communist-run island for more than a quarter century, until the U.S. capture of Venezuelan leader Nicolas Maduro in January.

The drying-up of that supply has pushed Cubans into a deeper level of survival mode as they contend with ever-longer blackouts and soaring prices for food and transportation as well as for fuel itself - when it is even available. Fuel shipments to Cuba from Mexico also halted recently, after the U.S. threatened tariffs on countries that supply oil to the island nation.

Some in Havana are increasingly turning to electric vehicles and scrambling to install solar panels atop their homes and businesses.

For Gabriela Barbon, 23, the ballooning transportation costs (three times higher than before to get around by car) persuaded her to get on a bike for the first time.

"Riding a bike is no longer just a hobby or something I wanted to do at some point in my life; it's a necessity," she said during a training session hosted by local organization Citykleta in a city park, alongside other adults finding their balance on two wheels for the first time.

"The Learn to Pedal campaign came at the perfect time, just when I needed it," she said.

Citykleta organizer Yasser Gonzalez expected 100 people to sign up, but the program has attracted nearly four times as many people - many seeking alternative ways to get around the Cuban capital.

"We have an avalanche of people who want to learn," he said, as a fellow organizer helped a first-timer on a bright blue bicycle.

Yoandris Herrera is not new to cycling. But he has stored his bicycle disassembled under his bed for almost a year, opting to zip around on a motorcycle instead.

The China-made bicycle, which he bought four years ago, now has a second chance on the streets as Herrera pedals to work and takes his kids to school.

"Since fuel is so expensive right now, it's more practical to get around by bicycle," he said.

The fuel crisis has also triggered more business for bicycle repairman Pedro Carrillo, who carefully aligned the spokes of a wheel at a makeshift workshop on a Havana sidewalk, with bicycle tires hanging on the wall behind him.

"It's been like an explosion," he said. But the biking boom itself has led to a new type of scarcity, too, he said. "Sometimes I don't have parts to help people. There are things I can't get anywhere."

data.title: RPC INC SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
RPC Inc., a leading provider of specialized oilfield services and equipment to the oil and gas industry, has released its 2025 10-K report. The report provides a comprehensive overview of the company's financial performance, business operations, strategic initiatives, and the challenges it faces in a highly competitive market. The following sections summarize the key highlights from the report.

Financial Highlights

  • Total Revenue: $1,626.6 million, an increase of 15.0% compared to 2024, primarily due to revenues from the recently acquired Pintail.
  • Operating Income: $44.7 million, a 54.1% decrease compared to the prior year, impacted by lower pricing and decreased activity in pressure pumping.
  • Net Income: $32.1 million, or $0.15 earnings per share, compared to net income of $91.4 million, or $0.43 earnings per share in 2024.
  • Net Income Margin: 2.0%, compared to 6.5% in 2024, reflecting the challenges in the pressure pumping market and increased competition.
  • Adjusted EBITDA: $232.7 million, with an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 14.3%, compared to $233.0 million and 16.5% in 2024, indicating stable operational performance despite market challenges.

Business Highlights

  • Revenue Segments: In 2025, Technical Services accounted for 94.4% of total revenues, with significant contributions from Pressure Pumping (29.8%), Downhole Tools (24.2%), and Wireline (19.4%). Support Services contributed 5.6% of total revenues, primarily from Rental Tools.
  • Geographical Performance: RPC provides services across major U.S. regions including Texas, the mid-continent, Gulf of America, Rocky Mountain, and Appalachian regions, with a concentration in the Permian basin for pressure pumping services.
  • Sales Units: The company ended 2025 with 10 horizontal frac fleets, including 3 Tier 4 DGB and 3 Tier 4 Diesel fleets, reflecting a focus on maintaining a modern and efficient fleet.
  • New Product Launches: RPC introduced new products such as a 3½ inch high-performance downhole motor and UnPlug, a proprietary alternative to traditional bridge plugs, enhancing its Downhole Tools service line.
  • Future Outlook: RPC anticipates ongoing consolidation in the OFS and E&P sectors, a reduction in rig count volatility due to capital discipline, and a favorable long-term outlook for natural gas demand. The company plans to focus on strategic investments to increase scale and diversify its service lines.

Strategic Initiatives

  • Acquisition: RPC, Inc. completed the acquisition of Pintail Alternative Energy, L.L.C., enhancing its oilfield services platform with a focus on the Permian Basin. This acquisition is expected to build on RPC's diversified services and geographic concentration in a key oil-producing region.
  • Systems Transformation: The company is implementing a multi-year systems transformation program to upgrade its ERP and supply chain systems, which is part of its strategic initiative to improve operational efficiency.
  • Capital Management: RPC, Inc. maintained a strong financial position with no outstanding borrowings under its $100 million revolving credit facility as of December 31, 2025. The company paid $35.1 million in dividends and repurchased $2.9 million of common stock in 2025. Additionally, RPC has a stock buyback program with 12,768,870 shares remaining available for repurchase. The company issued a secured note as part of the Pintail acquisition, with the first principal payment due in 2026.
  • Future Outlook: RPC plans to continue its capital expenditure strategy with expected spending between $150 million and $180 million in 2026, focusing on maintenance and growth opportunities. The company anticipates funding these expenditures primarily through operating cash flows and existing cash reserves. RPC also expects to continue paying dividends, subject to industry conditions and financial performance. The company is monitoring market conditions and customer preferences for efficient equipment, which may influence future strategic decisions.

Challenges and Risks

  • Market Competition: RPC operates in a highly competitive oilfield services (OFS) industry, facing significant price competition due to an oversupply of capacity, particularly in pressure pumping.
  • Industry Cyclicality: The company is impacted by the cyclical nature of the oil and gas industry, which can lead to financial instability and potential bankruptcies among OFS companies.
  • Weather Conditions: Adverse weather conditions can disrupt services and impact financial results.
  • Volatility of Oil and Gas Prices: The volatility of oil and natural gas prices significantly affects demand for RPC's services. A prolonged low level of customer activity in the oil and gas industry could adversely impact the company's financial condition.
  • Customer Concentration: The reliance on a large customer for a significant portion of revenues poses a risk if this customer reduces or ceases operations.
  • Credit Risk: The concentration of customers in the energy industry increases exposure to credit risk, especially during economic downturns.
  • Capital Spending: The company's success depends on capital spending by customers, many of whom rely on external financing, which could be constrained by elevated interest rates.
  • Key Personnel: The loss of key personnel could disrupt operations and affect revenues. The company faces challenges in attracting and retaining skilled workers, which could impact growth and profitability.
  • Supply Chain Disruptions: Supply chain disruptions and limited suppliers for certain materials could increase costs and reduce service availability.
  • Regulatory Compliance: Regulatory compliance, particularly regarding environmental laws and hydraulic fracturing, could increase operating costs and reduce demand for services.
  • Ownership Structure: The company's management and directors have substantial ownership, limiting public stockholders' influence and potentially impacting stock price volatility.
  • Market Risks: RPC is exposed to market risks, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices, which directly impact customer activity levels and demand for services. The company also faces risks related to interest rate changes, which could affect borrowing costs and financial flexibility. Additionally, geopolitical uncertainties and potential regulatory changes could influence market conditions and operational strategies.

SEC Filing: RPC INC [ RES ] - 10-K - Feb. 27, 2026

data.title: MARINE PRODUCTS CORP SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
Marine Products Corp, a leading manufacturer of fiberglass motorized boats under the Chaparral and Robalo brands, has released its 2025 10-K report. The report provides a comprehensive overview of the company's financial performance, business operations, strategic initiatives, and the challenges it faces in the current market environment.

Financial Highlights

Net Sales: $244.4 million, increased by 3.3% from 2024 due to a positive price/mix change of 9%, partially offset by a 6% decrease in unit sales volume.

Gross Profit: $46.8 million, up from $45.5 million in 2024, reflecting improved sales growth trends as field inventory positions improved.

Operating Income: $14.0 million, decreased from $18.3 million in 2024, primarily due to higher selling, general and administrative expenses.

Net Income: $11.4 million, down from $17.9 million in 2024, impacted by lower revenues and higher R&D investments.

Diluted Earnings Per Share: $0.32, decreased from $0.50 in 2024, reflecting the decline in net income.

Business Highlights

Product Lines: Marine Products offers a diverse range of fiberglass motorized boats under the Chaparral and Robalo brands. Chaparral focuses on sport boats, while Robalo targets the sport fishing market. The product lines include SSi Sport Boats, SSX Sport Boats, GTS - SURF, OSX Sport Boats, Robalo Center Consoles, Cayman Bay Boats, and Dual Consoles.

Manufacturing Facilities: The company's manufacturing operations are centralized in Nashville, Georgia, which is considered the largest single-site sport boat production plant in the U.S. This facility handles design, testing, and assembly, emphasizing manual production processes due to the customization and craftsmanship required.

Dealer Network: Marine Products distributes its boats through a network of 192 domestic and 84 international independent authorized dealers. The company supports its dealers with promotional efforts and sales incentive programs to stabilize manufacturing schedules and promote inventory replenishment.

Sales Units: In 2025, the company sold 2,354 boats, a decrease from 2,492 in 2024. The average gross selling price per boat increased to $93.6 thousand in 2025 from $85.7 thousand in 2024.

Geographical Performance: International sales accounted for 4.5% of net sales in 2025, down from 5.6% in 2024. The company has a presence in key states like Florida, Texas, Michigan, North Carolina, and Minnesota.

Research and Development: Marine Products invested $1.5 million in R&D in 2025, focusing on innovative product design and quality manufacturing processes. The company utilizes 3-D printing and virtual reality software to enhance product development.

Future Outlook: The company anticipates that the merger with MasterCraft will provide opportunities for growth and enhanced market presence. The merger is expected to be completed in 2026, subject to customary closing conditions.

Operational Challenges: The company faced challenges due to higher interest rates and increased costs of boat ownership, impacting consumer demand. Production levels have been adjusted to align with expected demand, and dealer inventories are being closely monitored.

Strategic Initiatives

Merger Agreement: Marine Products Corporation entered into a Merger Agreement with MasterCraft on February 5, 2026, which is expected to enhance the company's market position and provide stockholders with continued participation in the combined company's potential growth. The merger is structured to benefit from a stronger institutional following and is expected to incur substantial costs related to the transaction.

Capital Management: The company maintained a revolving credit facility with Truist Bank, providing a $20 million credit line, which is scheduled to mature on November 12, 2026. As of December 31, 2025, there were no outstanding borrowings under this facility. The company also declared a regular quarterly cash dividend of $0.14 per common share, payable on March 10, 2026. Additionally, the company has a stock buyback program authorized for the repurchase of up to 8,250,000 shares, with 1,570,428 shares remaining available for repurchase as of December 31, 2025. However, the Merger Agreement generally prohibits further repurchases during the period leading up to the merger completion.

Future Outlook: The company anticipates that the liquidity provided by existing cash, cash equivalents, and cash generated from operations will be sufficient to meet its requirements for at least the next twelve months. The Merger Agreement with MasterCraft imposes certain limitations on capital expenditures and indebtedness, which are expected to influence the company's capital management strategies until the merger is completed. If the merger is not completed during 2026, capital expenditures are expected to be between $1 million and $5 million. The company also expects to incur transaction-related costs associated with the merger, which will be funded by existing cash balances and operational cash flow.

Challenges and Risks

Operational Risks: Marine Products faces significant challenges due to its reliance on a single operational location in Nashville, Georgia. This concentration of operations increases vulnerability to catastrophic events such as natural disasters, which could disrupt manufacturing and supply chains. Additionally, the company is heavily dependent on its network of independent boat dealers for sales, with no long-term agreements in place, posing a risk to sales stability.

Market Risks: Economic conditions, including consumer confidence and credit availability, significantly impact Marine Products' sales, as boats are discretionary purchases. The company is also exposed to risks from interest rate fluctuations and fuel prices, which affect both dealer financing and consumer purchasing decisions. The reliance on third-party suppliers for raw materials and engines presents a risk of supply chain disruptions and cost increases. Furthermore, the company faces intense competition in the fragmented recreational boat industry, which could impact market share and profitability.

Regulatory Risks: Compliance with environmental and safety regulations could lead to increased costs or fines if not adhered to. The potential for new tariffs on imported materials could also increase production costs. Additionally, the company is under pressure to meet evolving ESG expectations, which could affect stakeholder relationships and brand reputation.

Financial Risks: The company has experienced a decrease in net income and operating income due to higher costs and lower sales volumes. Management is focusing on aligning production with demand and reducing costs. The recent merger agreement with MasterCraft introduces risks related to integration and realization of anticipated synergies. The fixed exchange ratio in the merger agreement means that stockholders face uncertainty regarding the market value of the stock consideration they will receive.

Interest Rate Risks: The company is dealing with the impact of high interest rates, which have increased the cost of boat ownership and affected consumer demand. Management is monitoring dealer inventories and adjusting production levels to align with market conditions. The potential failure to complete the merger could result in significant financial and operational disruptions.

Market Risks: Marine Products is exposed to market risks related to interest rate fluctuations, which affect both dealer financing costs and consumer purchasing power. The company also faces risks from potential changes in foreign currency exchange rates, as a portion of its sales are international. These market risks could adversely impact financial results and require strategic adjustments to mitigate their effects.

SEC Filing: MARINE PRODUCTS CORP [ MPX ] - 10-K - Feb. 27, 2026

data.title: Chubb Ltd SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
Chubb Ltd, a global insurance and reinsurance organization, has released its 2025 Form 10-K report, showcasing robust financial performance and strategic growth initiatives. The company operates in 54 countries and territories, offering a wide range of insurance products, including commercial and consumer property and casualty (P&C) insurance, accident and health (A&H), reinsurance, and life insurance. The report highlights significant increases in revenue and net income, strategic acquisitions, and a focus on digital transformation and climate risk management.

Financial Highlights

  • Total Revenues: $59,402 million, reflecting a 6.5% increase from 2024 driven by growth in net premiums written and net investment income.
  • Net Income: $10,622 million, a 10.0% increase from 2024, attributed to double-digit growth in P&C underwriting income and Life segment income.
  • Net Income Attributable to Chubb: $10,310 million, up 11.2% from 2024, driven by strong performance across segments.
  • Net Investment Income: $6,465 million, a 9.0% increase from 2024, primarily due to higher average invested assets from strong operating cash flow.
  • Net Realized Gains (Losses): $211 million, a significant improvement from $117 million in 2024, reflecting better market conditions.
  • Losses and Loss Expenses: $26,700 million, a 2.7% increase from 2024, indicating a moderate rise in claims and loss expenses.
  • Policy Benefits: $5,460 million, a 15.8% increase from 2024, primarily due to growth in international life operations.
  • Policy Acquisition Costs: $9,847 million, an 8.2% increase from 2024, reflecting higher business volumes.
  • Administrative Expenses: $4,504 million, a 2.8% increase from 2024, indicating effective cost management.
  • Interest Expense: $764 million, a 3.1% increase from 2024, reflecting changes in debt levels and interest rates.
  • Operating Cash Flow: $12.8 billion, highlighting strong cash generation capabilities.

Business Highlights

  • Global Operations: Chubb operates in 54 countries and territories, providing a wide range of insurance products. This extensive global presence supports a diverse client base and enhances the company's competitive advantage.
  • Segment Revenue Breakdown: Chubb's operations are divided into six business segments: North America Commercial P&C Insurance (38% of 2025 Consolidated NPE), North America Personal P&C Insurance (13%), North America Agricultural Insurance (5%), Overseas General Insurance (27%), Global Reinsurance (3%), and Life Insurance (14%).
  • North America Commercial P&C Insurance: This segment serves large, middle market, and small commercial businesses in the U.S., Canada, and Bermuda, offering a broad range of P&C, financial lines, and A&H products.
  • North America Personal P&C Insurance: Focused on high-net-worth individuals and families, this segment provides comprehensive personal insurance products such as homeowners, high-value automobile, and personal liability insurance.
  • Overseas General Insurance: This segment includes Chubb International and Chubb Global Markets, offering a range of commercial P&C and consumer lines products across Europe, Middle East, Africa, Asia, and Latin America. The acquisition of LMG Insurance in Thailand expanded operations in 2025.
  • Life Insurance Operations: Chubb Life operates primarily in Asia, offering a broad portfolio of protection and savings products. The segment focuses on maximizing opportunities in Asia, with significant operations in South Korea, mainland China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan.
  • New Acquisitions: In 2025, Chubb expanded its operations through the acquisition of LMG Insurance in Thailand and increased its ownership interest in Huatai Group to approximately 87.2%.
  • Digital Transformation: Chubb is enhancing its digital capabilities across various segments, including the establishment of the North America Small & Lower Midmarket Division, which leverages a modern, automated, and data-centric digital operating model.
  • Climate and Risk Management: Chubb recognizes the impact of climate change and incorporates it into its underwriting process, using catastrophe models to quantify natural catastrophe risk and adjust its risk management strategies accordingly.
  • Human Capital Management: Chubb employs approximately 45,000 people globally, with a focus on attracting, developing, and retaining top talent. In 2025, the company filled approximately 9,000 roles worldwide and continued to invest in employee development and well-being programs.
  • Future Outlook: Chubb's long-term business strategy focuses on sustained growth in book value through a combination of underwriting and investment income. The company aims to provide value to clients and shareholders by leveraging its substantial capital base in the insurance and reinsurance markets.

Strategic Initiatives

  • Strategic Initiatives: The company has focused on enhancing its financial flexibility and supporting growth through strategic capital allocation. This includes investments in technology and data analytics to improve operational efficiency and customer engagement. Additionally, the company has pursued strategic acquisitions to expand its market presence and product offerings, particularly in international markets.
  • Capital Management: The company has actively managed its capital structure by repurchasing shares and increasing dividends. In 2025, the company repurchased $500 million of its own shares, reflecting confidence in its long-term growth prospects. The quarterly dividend was increased by 10%, demonstrating a commitment to returning value to shareholders. The company also maintained a strong balance sheet with a focus on maintaining investment-grade credit ratings, supported by prudent debt management and liquidity enhancement measures.
  • Future Outlook: Looking ahead, the company plans to continue its disciplined approach to capital management, prioritizing investments that drive sustainable growth and shareholder value. This includes further share repurchases and potential dividend increases, contingent on market conditions and business performance. The company also aims to explore strategic partnerships and acquisitions that align with its growth strategy, particularly in emerging markets and digital innovation.

Challenges and Risks

  • Climate Change and Weather Patterns: Chubb faces challenges related to climate change and weather patterns, which are integral to its underwriting process. The company continually adjusts its process to address these changes, ensuring exposures are priced appropriately and losses are contained within its risk tolerance.
  • Acquisition Strategy: Chubb's acquisition strategy, including the recent acquisition of Cigna's business in Asian markets and a controlling interest in Huatai Insurance Group, presents integration risks and the challenge of maintaining profitability across diverse markets.
  • Natural and Man-Made Disasters: Chubb is exposed to significant risks from natural and man-made disasters, including climate change, which may increase the frequency and severity of catastrophes. The unpredictability of such events could lead to substantial volatility in financial results.
  • Cyber Risk: The company faces increasing cyber risk due to greater digital dependence, with potential losses from catastrophic cyber events.
  • Regulatory and Legal Risks: Legal, regulatory, and social responses to global climate change could impact Chubb's business. Additionally, the company may face challenges in accurately assessing loss reserves, which could affect financial results if actual claims exceed estimates.
  • Reinsurance Risks: Chubb's reliance on reinsurance presents risks, including the potential inability to purchase adequate reinsurance or the risk of non-payment by reinsurers.
  • Market Risks: The company's financial results are sensitive to market risks, including interest rate volatility, which could impact investment performance and capital resources.
  • Tax and Regulatory Changes: Regulatory changes, such as the new Bermuda Corporate Income Tax Act and OECD's global minimum tax regime, could increase Chubb's tax liabilities.
  • Privacy and Data Security: The company's operations are subject to complex and evolving privacy, data security, and AI regulations, which could increase compliance costs and risks of noncompliance.
  • Management Strategies: Management has identified the need to adapt to regulatory changes and geopolitical developments as a significant challenge. The company is focused on maintaining underwriting discipline and leveraging its global network to manage risks effectively.
  • Market Risk Exposure: Chubb is exposed to market risks, including fluctuations in interest rates and foreign currency exchange rates, which could adversely affect investment income and financial results. The company's investment portfolio, while primarily high-quality, includes a portion of below investment-grade securities, which carry higher credit or default risk.

SEC Filing: Chubb Ltd [ CB ] - 10-K - Feb. 27, 2026
